answers.answer: Liver enzymes raise for numerous reasons and not always due to liver damage. Test again in a few months as the enzyme levels may have lowered again.Etiology of ALT or AST elevations when less than 5 x normal:Common hepatic causes:AlcoholCirrhosisHepatitis B (chronic)Hepatitis C (chronic)Steatosis/steatohepatitisMedications/toxinsAcute viral hepatitisLess common hepatic causes:Autoimmune hepatitisHaemochromatosisAlpha1-antitrypsin deficiencyWilson's diseaseNonhepatic causes:Coeliac diseaseHaemolysisMyopathyThyroid imbalanceStrenuous exerciseMacro-ASTAs for diabetes, a major risk factor is magnesium deficiency.  Eating sugar does not cause diabetes."Magnesium plays a pivotal role in the secretion and function of insulin; without it, diabetes mellitus is inevitable." - Carolyn Dean, MD, ND.

question: My blood test this month showed AST at 51 and ALT at 93.  Previous annual blood tests have always been in the normal range.  Are these numbers dangerous?  Could this be a precursor to diabetes?  What can I do to reduce these numbers?I have replaced my wine each evening with ice cream and candy.  Could this be the cause?Wayne
title: Elevated AST & ALT
